etymology.description: 饣(食 ‘food’) + 昆 → 馄(hún) + 饣(食 ‘food’) + 屯 → 饨(tún) = wonton/dumpling in soup.
etymology.interpretation: Names small meat-filled dumplings served in broth. Characters were selected mainly for sound, with the food radical signaling something edible; often associated in folk etymology with 混沌.
etymology.simplification: Traditional 食-radical was simplified to 饣 in both characters: 餛→馄 and 飩→饨; phonetic parts 昆 and 屯 kept.

examples.chinese: 我最爱吃馄饨(我最愛吃餛飩)。
examples.english: I love eating wontons the most.

examples.chinese: 这家店的馄饨很鲜(這家店的餛飩很鮮)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiā diàn de húntun hěn xiān.
examples.english: The wontons at this shop are very fresh.

examples.chinese: 冬天来一碗馄饨最暖和(冬天來一碗餛飩最暖和)。
examples.pinyin: Dōngtiān lái yì wǎn húntun zuì nuǎnhuo.
examples.english: In winter, a bowl of wontons is the coziest.
